holidays.name: Nature Photography Day 📸🌿
holidays.description: A day dedicated to celebrating the art and skill of capturing the natural world through the lens of a camera. Whether it's a majestic mountain, a tiny insect, or a stunning sunset, this day encourages everyone to appreciate and document nature's beauty.
holidays.origin: Originated from the growing popularity of nature photography and social media sharing, aiming to raise awareness about wildlife and environmental conservation through stunning visuals.
holidays.funFact: The first known nature photograph dates back to the 1850s, making this hobby almost as old as photography itself!

holidays.name: Global Wind Day 🌬️🎐
holidays.description: An annual event to discover wind, its power, and the possibilities it holds to reshape energy production and fight climate change. People celebrate by flying kites, making pinwheels, and learning about wind energy.
holidays.origin: Established by the European Wind Energy Association and the Global Wind Energy Council to promote wind energy worldwide.
holidays.funFact: Wind turbines can be so tall that their blades can reach heights comparable to a 30-story building!

holidays.name: National Smile Power Day 😀💪
holidays.description: This uplifting holiday celebrates the incredible power of a smile. It's a reminder that a simple smile can boost mood, improve health, and even change someone's day for the better.
holidays.origin: Created as a mental health awareness initiative to emphasize the positive psychological effects of smiling and kindness.
holidays.funFact: Smiling, even when forced, can trick your brain into feeling happier due to the release of endorphins.

holidays.name: Glorious Gin & Tonic Day 🍸🍋
holidays.description: A tongue-in-cheek celebration of the classic cocktail that combines gin and tonic water. Whether enjoyed with a twist of lime or a sprig of rosemary, today’s the day to toast this bubbly concoction's refreshing magic.
holidays.origin: Unclear origins, but it celebrates the centuries-old drink that started as a medicinal beverage against malaria in British colonial times.
holidays.funFact: The quinine in tonic water, originally used for malaria prevention, gives the G&T its characteristic bitter taste.
